Convertible gilts give the holder of the gilt the choice to convert it into another gilt or receive the redemption payment on the redemption date.

Question 26

[1013331] Which of the following is true of gilts?
A
Usually pay interest monthly until redemption at a variable rate
B
Usually pay interest half-yearly until redemption at a variable rate
C
Usually pay interest half-yearly until redemption at a fixed rate
D
Do not pay interest
The correct answer is: C - Usually pay interest half-yearly until redemption at a fixed rate

Explanation

Most gilts pay fixed interest twice per year.

Question 1

[1013352] If interest rates remain the same, the price of a bond trading at a discount will tend to:
A
Rise in value as time passes
B
Fall in value as time passes
C
Remain the same as time passes
D
Fluctuate either up or down
The correct answer is: A - Rise in value as time passes

Explanation

This question is about the pull to redemption. A discount bond is one trading below its par value. If interest rates do not move, over time the bond's price will rise until, at redemption, it is worth its face, or par, value.

Question 2

[1013339] A bond, which pays an annual coupon of £5, is currently trading at par. Calculate the yield to maturity. You should answer this question by typing in percent in the following format without any symbols: 0
The correct answer is: 5 - 5

Explanation

If the bond is trading at face value, its yield to maturity (gross redemption yield) will be the same as the coupon.

Question 3

[1013360] The yield curve is the plot of:
A
Spot rate against time
B
Forward rate against time
C
Redemption yield against time
D
Flat yield against time
The correct answer is: C - Redemption yield against time

Explanation

The yield curve is a snapshot in time of the gross redemption yield on a range of fixed income securities. In the UK, gilts are used to construct the yield curve.

Question 4

[1013314] Which of the following is the best measure of corporate default risk?
A
The asset base
B
The profits of the company
C
The dividend history
D
The credit rating of the company
The correct answer is: D - The credit rating of the company

Explanation

There are two main credit rating companies: Moody's, and Standard and Poor's. Their task is to scrutinise a corporation's ability to pay interest and dividends on the securities they issue.

Question 5

[1066969] Which of the following bonds is likely to be the most volatile in terms of its sensitivity to changes in prevailing interest rates?
A
Neptune plc 5% 2018
B
Zeus plc 7.5% 2026
C
Adonis plc 3.5% 2015
D
Mercury plc 3% 2025
The correct answer is: D - Mercury plc 3% 2025

Explanation

Longer term bond with low coupons are the most volatile.

Question 6

[1013362] Which of the following is the definition of the current price of a redeemable fixed income security?
A
The sum of the present value of the remaining coupons and principal
B
The sum of the future value of the remaining coupons and principal
C
The sum of the present value of the remaining coupons
D
The present value of the principal
The correct answer is: A - The sum of the present value of the remaining coupons and principal

Explanation

In other words, all cash flows of the bond are discounted to their present value.

Question 7

[1013357] If a bond has a duration of five years and a yield of 10%, what is its modified duration? You should answer this question by typing in the following format without any symbols: 0.00
The correct answer is: 4.55 - 4.55

Explanation

Modified duration = duration / (1 + R). Therefore; MD = 5 years / 1.1 = 4.55%.

Question 8

[1013330] Which is the lowest 'investment grade' rating that Moody's will assign on a bond?
A
A
B
Ba
C
Baa
D
BBB
The correct answer is: C - Baa

Explanation

Default rates rise significantly below Baa. Hence, Baa and above are referred to as 'investment grade' credit ratings. BBB is Standard and Poor's lowest investment grade.

Question 9

[1024583] A bond is currently trading at £100 with a Gross Redemption Yield of 6% and has a duration of 3.7 years. Calculate the new price of the bond if yield rises to 7%.
A
103.70
B
96.30
C
103.49
D
96.51
The correct answer is: D - 96.51

Explanation

Modified duration = Duration / (1 + R). Therefore in this example: MD = 3.7 / 1.06 = 3.49%. Answers 103.70 and 103.49 misinterpret the inverse relationship between bond prices and interest rates. Answers 103.70 and 96.30 incorrectly use duration instead of modified duration.

Question 10

[1013359] If an undated bond with a coupon of 3% has a yield of 6%, what is its price? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 00
The correct answer is: 50 - 50

Explanation

Price of undated bond (perpetuity) = £3 / 0.06 = £50.

Question 11

[1013350] The clean price of a bond:
A
Excludes accrued interest
B
Includes accrued interest
C
Will always be lower than the dirty price
D
Will always be higher than the dirty price
The correct answer is: A - Excludes accrued interest

Explanation

The clean price (or net price) of a bond excludes any accrued interest. The dirty price (or gross price) includes accrued interest. Whether or not the price is higher depends on whether we are in the ex-div or the cum-div period.

Question 12

[1013364] Which theory of interest rates states that, 'in equilibrium', the long-term rate is a geometric average of today's short-term rate and expected short-term rates in the future'.
A
Yield curve
B
Market segmentation
C
Liquidity preference theory
D
Pure expectations theory
The correct answer is: D - Pure expectations theory

Explanation

In other words, if the market thinks that short-term rates are going to increase, long-term rates will be high (and vice-versa).

Question 13

[1023566] The relative importance of convexity for estimating bond price changes in response to interest rate changes increases under which of the following conditions?
A
When the interest rate shock is small
B
When the interest rate shock is large
C
When the interest rates are constant
D
Under all three specified conditions
The correct answer is: B - When the interest rate shock is large

Explanation

The larger the interest rate change (or shock) used when calculating the price change by the duration method, the more significant the adjustment due to the convex nature of the price-yield curve becomes.

Question 14

[1013354] A bond with three years remaining until maturity has an annual coupon of £8 and a gross redemption yield of 10%. What is the theoretical price of the bond? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 0.00
The correct answer is: 95.03 - 95.03

Explanation

Use the annuity formula to calculate the bond's price: £8 x 1 / 0.1 (1 - 1 / 1.1^3) + £100 / 1.1^3

Question 15

[1026832] In order to benefit from tax advantages, a REIT must retain no more than what percentage of income?
A
10%
B
15%
C
85%
D
90%
The correct answer is: A - 10%

Explanation

A REIT must distribute at least 90% of its income to benefit from the tax advantages given it by Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC). Therefore, it can retain no more than 10%.

Question 16

[1013358] If a bond has a duration of 8.4 years and a modified duration of 8, what is its yield? You should answer this question by typing in the following format without any symbols: 0
The correct answer is: 5 - 5

Explanation

Modified duration = duration / 1 + R. Therefore 8 = 8.4 years / (1 + R). Therefore 1 + R = 8.4/ 8 = 1.05. Therefore R = 1.05 - 1 = 0.05 or 5%.

Question 17

[1018096] Without the convexity adjustment it is likely that modified duration will:
A
Overestimate price rises and falls
B
Underestimate price rises and falls
C
Overestimate price falls and underestimate price rises
D
Overestimate price rises and underestimate price falls
The correct answer is: C - Overestimate price falls and underestimate price rises

Explanation

Modified duration is a linear assumption - it assumes that bond's prices move at a consistent rate in relation to a change in yields. This is not true, as the rate of change in a bond's price decreases as the yield increases, making the pricing curve of a bond convex. In order to price a bond effectively using modified duration, a convexity adjustment is necessary to account for the curve. Without this, modified duration will overestimate price falls and underestimate price rises. This is referred to as convexity error.

Question 18

[1013356] If a 6% long gilt pays interest twice a year, and the gross price 123 days into the coupon period is £45, what is the interest yield? You should answer this question by typing in the following format without any symbols: 0.00
The correct answer is: 13.96 - 13.96

Explanation

Interest yield = Gross annual coupon / clean price Gilts pay semi-annual coupons. This bond trades 123 days into the coupon period so has 123 days of accrued interest. Therefore ACCRUED interest = £6/2 x 123/182.5 days = £2.0219. If the dirty price is £45, we need to remove the accrued interest to calculate the clean price. Therefore clean price = £45 - £2.0219 = £42.98. Therefore interest yield (flat yield) = £6/£42.98 x 100 = 13.96%.

Question 19

[1015563] Why would an investor choose a CC-rated bond as opposed to an A-rated bond?
A
The CC-rated bond is more certain to pay-out
B
The A-rated bond is more risky
C
The CC-rated bond would give a higher potential return
D
The A-rated bond is classified as a junk bond and is not worth investing in
The correct answer is: C - The CC-rated bond would give a higher potential return

Explanation

The CC-rated bond has a lower credit bond, and therefore is a riskier investment; as such, it will have a higher-yield or return than the A-rated bond.

Question 20

[1066989] A 3-year zero-coupon £100NV bond is currently trading at £97. If the current interest rate is 7% what is the bond's Macaulay duration?
A
2.8 years
B
3 years
C
4 years
D
3.5 years
The correct answer is: B - 3 years

Explanation

The 'Macaulay duration' of a zero-coupon bond is its time to maturity.

Question 21

[1013363] Which of the following is/are true of bonds?
I
The higher the coupon, the lower the price
II
The higher the interest rate, the lower the price
III
The relationship between bond prices and the discount rate is non-linear
A
I and II only
B
II only
C
II and III only
D
III only
The correct answer is: C - II and III only

Explanation

There is an inverse relationship between interest rates and bond prices; if interest rates rise, bond prices fall. However, a 1% change in interest rates does not necessarily mean a 1% change in price (i.e. the relationship is non-linear).

Question 22

[1066988] A 3- year 5% £100NV bond is currently trading at £97. If the current interest rate is 7%, what is the bond's Macaulay duration?
A
2.86 years
B
2.86%
C
2.55 years
D
2.55%
The correct answer is: A - 2.86 years

Explanation

Question 23

[1066993] For an inverted yield curve which is true?
A
Forward > yield > spot
B
Yield > spot > forward
C
Yield < spot > forward
D
Forward < yield < spot
The correct answer is: B - Yield > spot > forward

Explanation

For a downward sloping yield curve, where the bonds are not zero-coupon, the forward < spot < yield. The reverse is true for an upward sloping yield curve.

Question 24

[1013343] What is meant by the clean price of a bond?
A
Includes accrued interest
B
Excludes accrued interest
C
The price in the ex-div period
D
The price in the cum-div period
The correct answer is: B - Excludes accrued interest

Explanation

The clean price is the price excluding accrued interest. The trade is done at the clean price but settled at the dirty price.

Question 25

[1048153] Which of the following assertions is NOT true in relation to a bond's convexity and modified duration?
A
The price-yield relationship predicted by modified duration is curved
B
Modified duration over-estimates the effect of price falls in predicting the change in price resulting from a change in yield
C
Convexity refers to the degree of curvature of the bond's price-yield relationship
D
The price-yield relationship predicted by modified duration is linear
The correct answer is: A - The price-yield relationship predicted by modified duration is curved

Explanation

The price-yield relationship predicted by modified duration is linear, not curved. This gives rise to inaccuracies in the prediction that modified duration makes regarding the change in price resulting from a change in yield of the bond.

Question 26

[1013344] Which of the following 15-year bonds will have the highest modified duration?
A
2.00% Japanese government bond
B
6.50% US bond
C
3.50% Italian bond
D
3.25% German bond
The correct answer is: A - 2.00% Japanese government bond

Explanation

Modified duration is a measure of the bond's risk. The higher the risk, the greater the modified duration. All the bonds in the question have the same redemption date; therefore, the lowest coupon bond, the Japanese government bond, will have the highest modified duration.

Question 27

[1013361] If interest rates are expected to fall the yield curve will be:
A
Flat
B
Downward-sloping
C
U-shaped
D
Upward-sloping
The correct answer is: B - Downward-sloping

Explanation

This is an application of pure expectation theory.

Question 28

[1013355] A 4% long Treasury bond pays interest half-yearly. Mid-way between payments the gross price is £58. What is the flat yield? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in percent in the following format without symbols: 0.00
The correct answer is: 7.02 - 7.02

Explanation

Half-yearly interest payments = £2. Therefore, mid-way through a payment period means there is £1 accrued interest in the gross (dirty) price. Therefore net (clean) price = £57. Flat-yield = coupon / clean price = 4/57 x 100 = 7.02%.

Question 29

[1013349] An investor buys a gilt for £105 immediately after it has paid its annual coupon of 8%, and sells it one year later immediately after receiving the coupon, thereby achieving a total return of 4.76%. The sale price received, therefore, was: You should answer this question by typing in pounds sterling in the following format without symbols: 0.00
The correct answer is: 102.00 - 102.00

Explanation

The total return to the investment includes capital gains and coupons received: £105 (start value) x 0.0476 = £5 (total return) As coupon is worth £8, investor must have realised a capital loss of £3 £8 - £3 = £5 (total return) Therefore £105-£3 = £102

Question 30

[1013346] If interest rates are expected to fall, which of the following actions should a bond fund manager take?
A
Hold long-dated, high coupon bonds
B
Hold short-dated, low coupon bonds
C
Hold long-dated, low coupon bonds
D
Hold short-dated, high coupon bonds
The correct answer is: C - Hold long-dated, low coupon bonds

Explanation

Remember, if yields fall then bond prices rise. A fund manager who expects yields to fall is going to want to profit from this event as much as possible, and will therefore seek to hold the most volatile bonds (those that will go up in value the most). The most volatile are those with the longest maturity date and lowest coupons.

Question 31

[1013341] If the market believes that short-term interest rates are going to rise, one would expect the yield curve to be:
A
Upward-sloping
B
Flat
C
Downward-sloping
D
'Humped'
The correct answer is: A - Upward-sloping

Explanation

The curve would be downward sloping if short-term interest rates are expected to decline.

Question 32

[1023974] Which of the following is the best description of the modified duration of a bond?
A
The change in the price of a bond for a given change in interest rates
B
The risk of the bond weighted to its maturity
C
The classification of a bond's maturity according to the Bond Markets Association
D
The return of a bond based on a sale and repurchase agreement
The correct answer is: A - The change in the price of a bond for a given change in interest rates

Explanation

This is the best definition of modified duration.

Question 33

[1013342] Which of the following is the lowest Standard and Poor's rating for investment grade debt?
A
D
B
AA-
C
Baa3
D
BBB-
The correct answer is: D - BBB-

Explanation

Standard and Poor's use all capital letters with + or - as modifiers, whereas Moody's use one capital letter and one or two lower case letter 'a' with 1,2 or 3 as modifiers.

Question 34

[1013348] Which of the following is implied by the 'liquidity preference theory' of the yield curve?
A
Maturity is only important for fixed interest stocks
B
Investors want a premium for shorter maturity investments
C
Investors want a premium for longer maturity investments
D
People are indifferent about maturity dates
The correct answer is: C - Investors want a premium for longer maturity investments

Explanation

The liquidity preference theory argues that investors require a higher return for longer dated investments. As a result, investors need to be tempted by higher yields. Consequently, the 'normal' shape of the yield curve should be upward sloping: i.e. lower yields for nearer-dated bonds and higher yields for longer-dated ones.

Question 35

[1066991] Juan is a 40% taxpayer and has calculated the NRY to be 5% on a 3 year £100NV 4% bond. What would the grossed up NRY be? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without any symbols: 0.000
The correct answer is: 8.333 - 8.333

Explanation

The grossed up NRY is the equivalent gross return on a fully taxed investment. 5% / 0.6 = 8.333%

Question 36

[1013216] The price of a two-year zero-coupon bond is £85.73. What is its internal rate of return?
A
6%
B
7%
C
8%
D
9%
The correct answer is: C - 8%

Explanation

The answer may be determined by trial and error: £85.73 x 1.06 x 1.06 = £96.33 £85.73 x 1.07 x 1.07 = £98.15 £85.73 x 1.08 x 1.08 = £100.00 £85.73 x 1.09 x 1.09 = £101

Question 37

[1013322] What is the highest rating assigned to bonds by Standard and Poor's?
A
Aa1
B
AA
C
AAA
D
Aaa
The correct answer is: C - AAA

Explanation

Note that the equivalent rating from Moody's is Aaa.

Question 38

[1012682] An investor buys an 8% gilt immediately after the coupon paid date for a price of £105. If she sells it 12 months later - again immediately after the coupon paid date - gaining an internal rate of return of 4.76%, what did the investor receive on the sale of the gilt?
A
£110
B
£107.87
C
£102
D
£100.23
The correct answer is: C - £102

Explanation

The investor makes a return of 4.76%. Therefore, £105 x 1.0476 = £110 However, the return includes the coupon payment of £8, so we do need to subtract that payment. £110 - £8 = £102.

Question 1

[1013377] What is the role the Bank of England plays in the UK T-bills market?
A
To control the amount of cash in the banking system
B
To control foreign exchange rates
C
To control unemployment
D
To promote speculation
The correct answer is: A - To control the amount of cash in the banking system

Explanation

The Bank of England uses T-bills to manage the amount of cash in the banking system (and interest rates).

Question 2

[1013368] Who normally issues CDs?
A
DMO
B
Treasury
C
Depositing institutions
D
Companies
The correct answer is: C - Depositing institutions

Explanation

Banks with a UK banking licence issue CDs in the UK.

Question 3

[1013375] The government issues a 180 day Treasury bill for a price of £9,700 with a par value of £10,000. What annual return does this represent to an investor who holds it to maturity, calculated on a simple basis?
A
3.00%
B
3.16%
C
6.27%
D
6.00%
The correct answer is: C - 6.27%

Explanation

You buy a T-bill for 9,700 and redeem for 10,000 making 300 profit on a 9,700 investment. 300/9,700 = 0.03093 This profit is over 180 days, so turn into an annual rate: 0.03093 x 365/180 = 0.0627 or 6.27%

Question 4

[1013369] One of the key roles played by Treasury bills is:
A
To be an instrument of controlling the amount of cash in the banking system
B
To raise long-term government finance
C
To influence transactions in the UK equity market
D
To help reduce the rate of inflation
The correct answer is: A - To be an instrument of controlling the amount of cash in the banking system

Explanation

The Bank of England uses T-bills to conduct open-market operations (OMOs). During OMOs, the bank is buying or selling T-bills in the London money market to either inject or remove cash to/from the banking system.

Question 5

[1013372] Certificates of deposit usually have maturities of:
A
12 months to five years
B
One month to one year
C
Three years to five years
D
Three months to 12 months
The correct answer is: B - One month to one year

Explanation

CD's are normally issued between one month and one year but can be as much as five years.

Question 6

[1013374] A purchases a CD from B in the secondary market. The credit risk to A is:
A
The risk of B defaulting
B
The risk of the issuer defaulting
C
Foreign exchange risk
D
The risk of interest rates changing
The correct answer is: B - The risk of the issuer defaulting

Explanation

A CD is supported by a deposit held by the issuer. The risk is that the issuer defaults.

Question 7

[1013367] The Edmonton Energy Company buys a CD via the secondary market from the Ilford Ink Company. The credit risk associated with this CD for the Edmonton Energy Company is:
A
The risk of the issuer defaulting
B
The risk of the Ilford Ink Company defaulting
C
The risk of an increase in interest rates
D
Re-investment risk at the maturity of the CD
The correct answer is: A - The risk of the issuer defaulting

Explanation

The issuers of CDs are banks. The credit risk lies with the issuing bank defaulting and not paying the holder of the CD the proceeds at maturity.

Question 8

[1013365] Who can issue CDs in the UK?
A
Banks and corporations with an AAA (or Aaa) credit rating
B
Any bank (or building society) with a UK banking licence
C
Any bank with a UK bank licence and an AAA (or Aaa) credit rating
D
Any bank with an AAA (or Aaa) credit rating
The correct answer is: B - Any bank (or building society) with a UK banking licence

Explanation

In the UK, only those institutions with a UK banking licence can issue CDs.

Question 9

[1013382] Which of the following best describes a certificate of deposit?
A
It is a corporate-issued discount instrument that pays no coupon
B
It is a government issued discount instrument that pays no coupon
C
It is a bank issued tradable time deposit
D
It is a corporate-issued time draft
The correct answer is: C - It is a bank issued tradable time deposit

Explanation

A certificate of deposit (CD) is a bearer instrument representing a time deposit. They do pay interest all at once at the maturity date (bullet).

Question 10

[1013370] Who uses T-bills and for what?
A
Provide long-term funding for the government
B
Provide short-term government funding
C
Provide long-term funding for companies
D
Provide short-term funding for companies
The correct answer is: B - Provide short-term government funding

Explanation

T-bills are short-term government securities. Short-term means less than one year to maturity.

Question 11

[1013366] Who normally issues CDs in London?
A
Companies
B
Banks and building societies
C
DMO
D
FCA
The correct answer is: B - Banks and building societies

Explanation

Banks and building societies with a UK banking licence can issue CDs - certificates of deposit.

Question 1

[1001327] The £ vs. $ rate is currently $1.6085 - 1.6095. The sterling equivalent of converting $100,000 is:
A
£61,131
B
£61,170
C
£62,131
D
£62,170
The correct answer is: C - £62,131

Explanation

Converting $100,000 means that we sell the dollars and buy sterling. We would therefore sell our dollars at 1.6095: $100,000 / 1.6095 = £62,131.

Question 2

[1001334] The forward adjustment is 200 for GBP / USD. By how much will that move the spot rate?
A
2
B
0.2
C
0.02
D
0.002
The correct answer is: C - 0.02

Explanation

The forward adjustment is measured in pips. A pip is the fourth and fifth significant figures of a quote. Cable is USD/GBP with GBP as the base currency. A movement of 200 pips would move the quote by 0.0200 US dollars.

Question 3

[1001326] If the Japanese yen is quoted at a premium to sterling on the forward foreign exchange markets, then the forward quote should be:
A
Added to the spot rate
B
Deducted from the spot rate
C
The same as the spot rate
D
Impossible to say from the given information
The correct answer is: B - Deducted from the spot rate

Explanation

A premium on yen in the forward markets implies that the yen is getting more expensive. You will therefore be getting LESS yen for your £1 sterling. Although it might at first seem counter-intuitive, a premium is DEDUCTED from spot while a discount is ADDED.

Question 4

[1012665] Which of the following is the settlement convention for FX on a delivery versus payment basis?
A
T+2
B
T+5
C
T+3
D
Real time
The correct answer is: A - T+2

Explanation

Standard FX settlement is T+2.

Question 5

[1001828] The current spot quote is $1.7920-$1.7930 per £1. The forward quote is 30-28 pips. At what price can a client buy a US dollar forward? You should answer this question by typing in the following format without symbols: 0.0000
The correct answer is: 1.7890 - 1.7890

Explanation

The spot rate needs to be adjusted by the forward rate adjustment. As 28 is less than 30 we subtract the adjustment from the spot rate. (1.7920 - 1.7930) - (0.0030 - 0.0028) = 1.7890 - 1.7902 The rate to buy USD will be 1.7890.

Question 6

[1001330] The spot sterling vs. the dollar rate is 1.4400. The three-month forward rate is at a 20/18 adjustment. For someone who wants to change sterling to dollars, what would the three-month forward rate be? You should answer this question by typing in the following format without symbols: 0.0000
The correct answer is: 1.4380 - 1.4380

Explanation

The adjustment gives a 3m forward rate of $1.4380/$1.4382. We wish to sell base, so the quoting bank's bid rate is the relevant one.

Question 7

[1001325] Which of the following is false of the currency markets?
A
Both spot transactions and forward transactions are offered
B
All transactions are guaranteed by the International Currency Clearing House
C
There is no fixed market place
D
Brokers operate to link buyers with sellers
The correct answer is: B - All transactions are guaranteed by the International Currency Clearing House

Explanation

The currency market is a huge over-the-counter market - there is no fixed market place. Settlement-of-currency transactions are processed directly between the counterparties to the trade. There is no central counterparty operating in the markets protecting against default. The brokers operating in the currency markets are called 'money brokers'. Spot settlement for currency transactions is T+2.

Question 8

[1001328] Which of the following is true of the currency markets?
A
Trading takes place on exchange
B
Not regulated by the FCA
C
London is the largest centre for trading
D
Spot deals settle T+1
The correct answer is: C - London is the largest centre for trading

Explanation

The FX markets are OTC (over-the-counter). Standard spot settlement is T+2. They are regulated in London by the FCA.

Question 9

[1001324] The dollar vs. the sterling rate is currently $1.5585 - 1.5595. The dollar equivalent for an investor of converting £100,000 into US dollar is:
A
$155,850
B
$155,950
C
$64,164
D
$64,123
The correct answer is: A - $155,850

Explanation

£100,000 x 1.5585 = $155,850.

Question 10

[1013400] If the inflation rates in the US and UK were 3% and 5% respectively, and the UK nominal interest rate was 6%, what would the US nominal interest rate be?
A
2.0%
B
4. 0%
C
6. 0%
D
8.0%
The correct answer is: B - 4. 0%

Explanation

Use the Fisher Effect formula:

Question 11

[1001710] Sterling is quoted at a $1.4735-1.4770 spot. The one-month forward is quoted at a premium of 15-10 pips. How much in US dollars will it cost to buy £100,000 for settlement in one month? You should answer this question by typing in the following format without symbols: 0,000
The correct answer is: 147,600 - 147,600

Explanation

The one-month forward rate is $1.4720-$1.4760 (i.e. deduct premium). We wish to buy the base currency; the quoting bank will therefore deal at its offer $1.4760. £100,000, and will therefore cost $147,600.

Question 12

[1008096] What is the delivery time for a spot transaction?
A
Two business days
B
Five business days
C
One business day
D
Ten business days
The correct answer is: A - Two business days

Explanation

Delivery for a spot transaction takes place within two business days.

Question 13

[1001323] Which of the following is true of timing for settlement of spot foreign exchange transactions?
A
Same day
B
T+2
C
T+5
D
T+7
The correct answer is: B - T+2

Explanation

However, there is no standard settlement of forward currency transactions.

Question 14

[1012670] You invested $1,200 when the exchange rate was $1.50 = £1. Two years later, your investment is worth $1,485 and the exchange rate is $1.65 = £1. What is the time-weighted average rate of return in terms of GBP?
A
6.07%
B
11.88%
C
6.25%
D
11.24%
The correct answer is: A - 6.07%

Explanation

You invested £800 two years ago (1200 / 1.50), and this is worth £900 now (1485 / 1.65). Your total return is 12.50% (100 / 800). To find the geometric average, we take the square root of 1.125 (1 plus 12.5%), which gives us 6.07%.

Question 15

[1001329] If the sterling vs. the dollar spot rate is 1.7180-1.7270 and the three-month forward rate adjustment is 42-44, how many dollars need to be sold to raise £150,000 in three months' time? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 000,000
The correct answer is: 259,710 - 259,710

Explanation

The investor wishes to sell dollars (so buys pounds). As the investor is buying base, the higher rate is used: 1.7270 US dollar. Add forward rate 'disc' (discount) to the spot rate: 1.7270 + 0.0044 = 1.7314 Finally calculate the number of dollars that need to be sold: £150,000 x 1.7314 = $259,710

Question 1

[1013426] 'American' style equity options can be exercised:
A
Only at expiry
B
At any time up to and including expiry
C
Every Friday up to the expiry date
D
Never
The correct answer is: B - At any time up to and including expiry

Explanation

Note that 'European' style options are exercised only at expiry.

Question 2

[1013428] Time value in an option premium equals:
A
Intrinsic value
B
The lower of intrinsic value (if any) and total premium
C
Intrinsic value (if any) less total premium
D
Total premium less intrinsic value (if any)
The correct answer is: D - Total premium less intrinsic value (if any)

Explanation

Total premium = intrinsic value (if any) + time value

Question 3

[1013443] Who clears trades on NYSE Liffe?
A
CREST
B
CGO
C
Euroclear
D
LCH.Clearnet
The correct answer is: D - LCH.Clearnet

Explanation

LCH.Clearnet acts as a central counterparty for trades executed on NYSE Liffe.

Question 4

[1013435] What is a rise or fall of one index point worth in the FTSE 100 futures contract? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in pounds sterling in the following format without symbols: 0
The correct answer is: 10 - 10

Explanation

NYSE Liffe specifies the contact value at £10 per full index point.

Question 5

[1026858] Which of the following is the best description of an equity swap?
A
A contract where one party pays a floating rate of interest and receives the return on an index or share
B
A contract for the difference between the return on two different shares
C
A contract where the return on a share or index passes, while the capital in the transaction is protected
D
A physically delivered contract involving the return on a share or index
The correct answer is: A - A contract where one party pays a floating rate of interest and receives the return on an index or share

Explanation

A represents the best description of an equity swap. Equity swaps are cash-settled.

Question 6

[1013418] I buy three FTSE 100 futures contracts at 5,010 and sell at 5,210. What is the profit/loss? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format: +0,000 or -0,000
The correct answer is: +6,000 - +6,000

Explanation

Total profit: 200 index points per contract x £10 per index point x 3 contracts = £6,000.

Question 7

[1017337] Which of the following would be out-of-the money options?
I
A call option where the price of the underlying is above the exercise price
II
A call option where the price of the underlying is below the exercise price
III
A put option where the price of the underlying is above the exercise price
IV
A put option where the price of the underlying is below the exercise price
A
I and II
B
II and IV
C
II and III
D
I and IV
The correct answer is: C - II and III

Explanation

A call option is out-of-the-money if the strike is higher than the value of the underlying. A put option is out-of-the-money if the strike is lower than the value of the underlying.

Question 8

[1012686] Which of the following futures contracts are physically delivered on LIFFE?
A
FTSE 100 index
B
STIR
C
US Dollar/Euro
D
6% Notional Gilt
The correct answer is: D - 6% Notional Gilt

Explanation

All of the others are contracts on LIFFE, but are contracts for difference (CFD), i.e. they are cash settled.

Question 9

[1013449] On the NYSE Liffe market, what is the purpose of variation margin?
A
Cover adverse movements expected over the next week
B
An initial deposit to cover the maximum likely daily loss on a futures contract
C
Cover adverse movements in value from the previous day
D
Cover adverse movements from the previous week
The correct answer is: C - Cover adverse movements in value from the previous day

Explanation

Variation margin can be a receipt or a payment. It represents the profit or loss on open derivative positions, which result from changes in underlying asset values from the previous day.

Question 10

[1013413] Which of the following are advantages of futures clearing through LCH.Clearnet?
I
Increased liquidity
II
Lower settlement costs
III
Reduced counterparty risk
A
I, II and III
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
I and II
The correct answer is: A - I, II and III

Explanation

Liquidity is improved relative to the associated cash market. Counterparty risk is removed by LCH.Clearnet acting as central counterparty.

Question 11

[1032173] Which of the following is not true of an equity swap?
A
The payer of dividends has to own the underlying stock or index
B
The swap will have a termination date
C
The notional amount may be fixed or variable
D
Payments of equity returns are in arrears
The correct answer is: A - The payer of dividends has to own the underlying stock or index

Explanation

Equity swaps are derivative contracts and therefore allow leveraged positions to be taken on the underlying without ownership of it.

Question 12

[1013453] If everything else remained constant, increases in which of the following would always increase American option premiums?
I
Volatility
II
Interest rates
III
Remaining life
IV
Price of the underlying instruments
A
I and II
B
I and IV
C
I and III
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: C - I and III

Explanation

The more volatile/risky the underlying is, the more expensive all options will become. The remaining life will also always increase an option's time value. An increase in interest rates or in the price of the underlying will increase calls but decrease puts.

Question 13

[1016993] A writer of a put option is at risk of incurring a loss if which of the following occurs?
A
An increase in the price of the underlying asset
B
A decrease in the price of the asset
C
They will not be affected by either an increase or decrease
D
If the price of the asset stays the same
The correct answer is: B - A decrease in the price of the asset

Explanation

A holder of a long-put contract will exercise the option if the price of the underlying falls.

Question 14

[1013422] An investor buys a put option with an exercise price of £10.50 when the underlying share price is £12. The option is:
A
In-the-money
B
It depends on the premium paid
C
At-the-money
D
Out-of-the-money
The correct answer is: D - Out-of-the-money

Explanation

A put option (the right to sell at a fixed price) becomes valuable as the price of the underlying asset falls below the exercise price. As asset prices rise above the exercise price, the option is worthless (or 'out-the-money').

Question 15

[1013420] When a futures contract is closed-out:
A
The contract is delivered
B
The counterparty has defaulted on the contact
C
Delivery is extended
D
The opposite future's position is taken-out
The correct answer is: D - The opposite future's position is taken-out

Explanation

'Closing-out' is achieved by taking out a negatively correlated contract. E.g. a long-position closes out an existing short-position and vice-versa.

Question 16

[1013408] Consider two put options with different strike prices. The option with the lower strike price will normally:
A
Have the higher premium
B
Have the lower premium
C
Have greater volatility
D
Both options will have the same premium
The correct answer is: B - Have the lower premium

Explanation

A put option is the right to sell. At any given time the option with the higher strike price will be more valuable. Volatility is a characteristic of the underlying asset.

Question 17

[1013417] What is the tick value of the FTSE 100 future?
A
£1
B
£5
C
£10
D
£100
The correct answer is: B - £5

Explanation

The minimum price movement (or 'tick') is half an index point. The contract value, specified by NYSE Liffe, is £10 per index point. The tick value is therefore £5.

Question 18

[1013452] What is the intrinsic value of an equity index 1,260 put option if, at expiry, the index value is 1,270?
A
-10
B
1,260
C
Nil
D
+10
The correct answer is: C - Nil

Explanation

The right to sell at 1,260 would be worthless if, at expiry, the underlying asset was at 1,270. The option therefore has zero intrinsic value. Note: intrinsic value cannot be negative.

Question 19

[1066976] A copper mining company has hedged its exposure to falling oil prices by buying oil futures. Although it is fully hedged, it could be exposed to:
A
Liquidity risk
B
Specific risk
C
Default risk
D
Basis risk
The correct answer is: D - Basis risk

Explanation

Even with a fully hedged position, an investor is subject to basis risk if the position is closed before delivery. As futures are exchange-traded, default risk is not an issue.

Question 20

[1013414] A fund manager has a portfolio of UK government loan stock, and is concerned that interest rates may rise. Which of the following strategies would be a suitable hedge?
I
Buy long gilt call options
II
Sell long gilt futures
III
Buy long gilt futures
IV
Buy long gilt put options
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
II and IV
D
III and IV
The correct answer is: C - II and IV

Explanation

If interest rates were to rise gilts prices would fall. The two suitable strategies for hedging against a fall in gilt prices are buying a put and selling a future.

Question 21

[1013444] An option's delta is best described as the ratio between:
A
The price of the option and the price of the underlying instrument
B
The change in the option premium and the change in the price of the underlying instrument
C
The time value and the intrinsic value
D
The option premium and the underlying price
The correct answer is: B - The change in the option premium and the change in the price of the underlying instrument

Explanation

The Delta of an option quantifies how far a premium changes given a change in the price of the underlying asset. Note: Delta = change in premium / change in underlying.

Question 22

[1013407] Variation margin called by LCH.Clearnet for NYSE Liffe contracts is:
A
An initial down payment on a position
B
A payment to cover adverse price changes in the week ahead
C
A payment to cover adverse price changes in the previous week
D
A payment to cover adverse price changes in the previous day
The correct answer is: D - A payment to cover adverse price changes in the previous day

Explanation

Variation margin is calculated at the end of each day by LCH.Clearnet 'marking-to-market' a member's position. It therefore reflects profits and losses from the previous day.

Question 23

[1013412] Which of the following best defines what variation margin payments cover?
A
Adverse movements expected over the next week
B
Initial payment to cover future movement in price
C
Adverse movements in value from the previous day
D
Adverse movements from the previous week
The correct answer is: C - Adverse movements in value from the previous day

Explanation

Variation margin can be a receipt or a payment. It represents the profit or loss on open derivative positions, which result from changes in underlying asset values from the previous day.

Question 24

[1012668] You are a fund manager for Trey Stooges Funds and would like to hedge your equity holdings of around £100 million using the September FTSE100 futures, which are currently at 1053. What is the hedge rate?
A
Buy 10,000
B
Sell 10,000
C
Buy 9,497
D
Sell 9,497
The correct answer is: D - Sell 9,497

Explanation

£100m/ (1053 x £10) = 9,497 Sell 9,497 to hedge an underlying long position.

Question 25

[1013442] Why would a portfolio manager holding equities use futures?
I
Futures are more liquid than the underlying equities
II
Futures' transaction costs are cheaper than the underlying equities
III
To increase leverage
A
I only
B
II only
C
I, II and III
D
II and III
The correct answer is: C - I, II and III

Explanation

Other advantages include the ability to take a short-position and execute trades more quickly than in the cash market.

Question 26

[1013416] How would an investor maximise return in the US equity market if no change in the market is expected?
A
Buy call options on the S&P index
B
Sell call options on the S&P index
C
Buy put options on the S&P
D
Sell futures on the S&P index
The correct answer is: B - Sell call options on the S&P index

Explanation

By selling call options, the investor will receive premiums even if prices remain unchanged.

Question 27

[1013450] If an investor believes that US equity prices will remain unchanged, which of the following is most appropriate?
A
Buy US equity index futures
B
Buy US equity index puts
C
Sells US equity index futures
D
Sell US equity index calls
The correct answer is: D - Sell US equity index calls

Explanation

Futures will make money if prices go up (long futures' positions) or down (short futures' positions). A long-put will make money if prices fall, but if they remain unchanged, the premium is lost. The only response in this question which makes money (the premium), if prices remain the same, is the short-call.

Question 28

[1013441] If two put options have identical expiry dates, the option with the lower exercise price will:
A
Have a lower premium
B
Not require margin payments
C
Be at-the-money
D
Have a higher premium
The correct answer is: A - Have a lower premium

Explanation

Put options increase in value as the value of the underlying asset falls. With a lower exercise price, underlying asset prices have to fall further before the option becomes valuable (moves 'in-the-money'). If an option is (relatively) less valuable, the premium will be (relatively) cheaper.

Question 29

[1013427] 'European' style options may be exercised:
A
Never
B
Every Friday up to the expiry date
C
At any time up to and including expiry
D
Only at expiry
The correct answer is: D - Only at expiry

Explanation

Note that 'American' style options can be exercised anytime up to and including expiry.

Question 30

[1013429] Intrinsic value for a put option equals:
A
Exercise price less share price
B
Share price less exercise price
C
The greater of share price and exercise price
D
Time value
The correct answer is: A - Exercise price less share price

Explanation

A put option is in-the-money (has intrinsic value) when share price falls below the exercise price.

Question 31

[1013439] The prices of interest rate futures are quoted as:
A
A negative absolute interest rate
B
100 plus an interest rate
C
100 minus an interest rate
D
A positive absolute interest rate
The correct answer is: C - 100 minus an interest rate

Explanation

Interest rate futures are quoted as an 'index': i.e. less the implied rate.

Question 32

[1013436] An investor buys a FTSE 100 index future at 6,110. At expiry of the future the index is 6,200. What is your profit? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without symbols: 000
The correct answer is: 900 - 900

Explanation

The gain is 90 index points. At £10 per index point, the total profit is £900.

Question 33

[1013440] What is 'contango' in relation to futures markets?
A
When the cash price is greater than the futures price
B
When the offer price exceeds the bid price
C
When the futures price is greater than the cash price
D
When the bid price exceeds the offer price
The correct answer is: C - When the futures price is greater than the cash price

Explanation

Contango is the normal situation in the futures markets, where the future's price exceeds the cash price of the underlying asset. If the reverse is true, the market is said to be in 'backwardation'.

Question 34

[1013454] The September three-month interest rate future is trading at 96.45. What does this imply if the interest rate is for a three-month deposit starting in September?
A
9.645%
B
3.55%
C
96.45%
D
5.425%
The correct answer is: B - 3.55%

Explanation

The price of the interest rate future contract traded on NYSE Liffe is 100 minus the implied interest rate (100 - 96.45).

Question 35

[1013406] Which one of the following best describes the difference between an American and a European style option:
A
American options are traded in the USA, whilst European options are traded on European exchanges only
B
Unlike the latter, the former cannot be sold
C
Unlike the latter, the former cannot be executed
D
Unlike the former, the latter cannot be exercised before expiration
The correct answer is: D - Unlike the former, the latter cannot be exercised before expiration

Explanation

The terms American and European in respect of options relate purely to the flexibility of exercise: Americans may be executed prior to expiry; whereas Europeans can only be exercised on the expiry date.

Question 36

[1012663] A call option has a strike price of 120p and a premium of 7p. If the current share price is 94p which of the following represents the intrinsic value? You should answer the question by typing in the following format without symbols: 0
The correct answer is: 0 - 0

Explanation

The option is out of the money and therefore has no intrinsic value.

Question 37

[1012664] A fund manager holds a £5m portfolio of well diversified UK shares and wishes to hedge using the FTSE 100 index future @ 5030. Calculate the hedge ratio.
A
Sell 100 futures
B
Sell 1000 futures
C
Buy 100 futures
D
Buy 1000 futures
The correct answer is: A - Sell 100 futures

Explanation

The FTSE 100 index future is cash settled at £10 per point. 5m/ (5030 x £10) = 99.4. i.e. sell 100 futures.

Question 38

[1013424] LCH.Clearnet is:
A
A department of the Treasury
B
The futures and options market regulator
C
The clearing house for trades conducted on LSE
D
An exempt person
The correct answer is: D - An exempt person

Explanation

LCH.Clearnet is a recognised clearing house and, as such, is exempt from the requirement to gain FCA authorisation under the FSMA 2000.

Question 39

[1013423] Which organisation acts as central counterparty and clearing house for NYSE Liffe trades?
A
LCH.Clearnet
B
RCH
C
OM London Exchange
D
CREST
The correct answer is: A - LCH.Clearnet

Explanation

LCH.Clearnet is a recognised clearing house (RCH) which acts as central counterparty for trades executed on NYSE Liffe, LME, IPE, and for SETS securities.

Question 40

[1013445] What is the initial margin on NYSE Liffe based on?
A
A fixed % of the contract value
B
A fixed % of the anticipated daily movement
C
The credit risk of the clearing member
D
The maximum likely daily loss arising from a futures contract
The correct answer is: D - The maximum likely daily loss arising from a futures contract

Explanation

Initial margin is required by the clearing house to avoid 'credit risk' - the risk that clearing members will not be able to clear any deficit at the end of a day's trading.

Question 41

[1013447] Which of the following best describes how the majority of business is conducted on NYSE Liffe?
A
Open outcry
B
Over-the-counter
C
Electronic order-driven
D
Quote-driven
The correct answer is: C - Electronic order-driven

Explanation

NYSE Liffe uses an electronic trading platform called NYSE Liffe connect.

Question 42

[1013446] A fund manager wants to hedge an equity fund of £20m with a Beta of 0.5. The FTSE 100 future is currently quoted at 6,100. How many contracts should be sold (to the nearest contract) in order to provide a hedge? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without any symbols: 000.00
The correct answer is: 164.00 - 164.00

Explanation

(£20m / £61,000) x 0.5 = 164 contracts.

Question 43

[1013438] What happens to the buyer of a NYSE Liffe long bond future at delivery?
A
Obliged to deliver a bond
B
Obliged to take delivery of a bond
C
Takes any profit or loss in cash
D
Settles into an option position
The correct answer is: B - Obliged to take delivery of a bond

Explanation

The underlying asset of the NYSE Liffe long bond future is a NOTIONAL bond. However, at delivery NYSE Liffe produces a list of 'deliverable bonds', which are REAL bonds available for delivery. The buyer of a long bond future is consequently obliged to take delivery of a real bond selected by the seller.

Question 44

[1013451] Which of the following options are regarded as in-the-money?
I
Call option at 120p; current share price 115p
II
Call option at 120p; current share price 170p
III
Put option at 220p; current share price 115p
IV
Put option at 120p; current share price 140p
A
I and II only
B
II and III only
C
I and IV only
D
III and IV only
The correct answer is: B - II and III only

Explanation

A call option is in-the-money when its strike is BELOW the underlying. A put is in-the-money when its strike is ABOVE the strike price.

Question 45

[1013419] An investor sells 14 FTSE 100 futures contracts at 6,000 and closes out at 6,500. What is his profit/loss (1pt = £10)?
A
Profit £70,000
B
Profit £5,000
C
Loss £70,000
D
Loss £5,000
The correct answer is: C - Loss £70,000

Explanation

Total loss: 500 index points per contract x £10 per index point x 14 contracts = £70,000.

Question 46

[1013433] You hold one NYSE Liffe FTSE 100 index call option contract with an exercise price of 6,000. The index currently stands at 6,020. Ignoring premium costs and commissions, which of the following is true? (The option is priced at £10 an index point)
A
You are 'in-the-money' by £20
B
You are 'out-of-the-money' by £20
C
You are 'in-the-money' by £200
D
You are 'out-of-the-money' by £200
The correct answer is: C - You are 'in-the-money' by £200

Explanation

Exercising the option would lead to a gain of 20 points. At £10 per index point, the total gain (intrinsic value) is £200. If an option has intrinsic value it is 'in-the-money'.

Question 47

[1013430] In-the-money for an equity call option means:
A
The premium is always zero
B
The exercise price equals the share price
C
The exercise price is more than the share price
D
The exercise price is less than the share price
The correct answer is: D - The exercise price is less than the share price

Explanation

A call option has intrinsic value when share price exceeds exercise price. The holder can then exercise his right and buy a share for less than its current value.

Question 48

[1017611] What is the most accurate definition of a future?
A
A right via an agreement to buy or sell a given quantity of a particular asset at a set future date and at a pre-agreed price
B
A binding agreement to buy or sell a variable quantity of a particular asset at a set future date and at a pre-agreed price
C
A right via an agreement to buy or sell a variable quantity of a particular asset at a set future date and at a pre-agreed price
D
A binding agreement to buy or sell a given quantity of a particular asset at a set future date and at a pre-agreed price
The correct answer is: D - A binding agreement to buy or sell a given quantity of a particular asset at a set future date and at a pre-agreed price

Explanation

Futures are binding agreements or a contract. By definition, a future is traded on exchange and subject to significant contract specifications.

Question 49

[1013410] If the fund manager of a gilt portfolio was concerned about an increase in interest rates, what could he do to hedge his position?
I
Sell gilt futures
II
Buy gilt futures
III
Buy put options
IV
Sell put options
A
I and III
B
I and II
C
II and III
D
III only
The correct answer is: A - I and III

Explanation

Increased rates mean lower prices - therefore the manager needs to set selling prices in advance - by selling futures and buying put options.

Question 50

[1013431] When share price is 25p, the intrinsic value of a call option with an exercise price of 40p will be:
B
25
C
40
D
65
The correct answer is: A - 0

Explanation

Intrinsic value cannot be negative. For a call option, if exercise price exceeds share price, then there is no 'built-in profit'. Intrinsic value is therefore nil.

Question 51

[1013434] An investor buys a put with an exercise price of 90p for a premium of 21p. What is the maximum possible overall profit?
A
21
B
69
C
90
D
111
The correct answer is: B - 69

Explanation

The theoretical maximum profit is obtained by selling the underlying asset for the exercise price, when it is worth nothing. In this question, this would lead to a gain of 90p. However, in order to buy the option, a premium of 21p has to be paid. The overall profit is therefore (90p - 21p) 69p.

Question 52

[1013421] How is the NYSE Liffe FTSE 100 index futures contract settled?
A
Cash or physical delivery of stock, at the option of the buyer
B
Cash
C
Delivery of the index
D
Physical delivery of stock
The correct answer is: B - Cash

Explanation

The FTSE 100 future is a 'contact for difference'. This means it is cash-settled.

Question 53

[1066831] Which of these descriptions correctly identifies the STIR contract?
A
Physically delivered and based on a £100,000 nominal value
B
Cash settled and with a tick size of 0.5 points
C
Physically delivered and based on 1000 minus the BOE rate.
D
Based on a 3- month period and £500,000 notional value
The correct answer is: D - Based on a 3- month period and £500,000 notional value

Explanation

The sterling short term NYSE Liffe interest rate contract is based upon the interbank rate for a deposit of £0.5m. It is known as the 'short sterling' interest rate future. The contract guarantees to the holder the price for borrowing sterling over a three-month period commencing when the contract expires. This contract is cash-settled, rather than settled with the delivery of the asset to the contract holder. Interest rate futures are priced as 100 minus the rate of interest. The tick size on three-month sterling contracts is one basis point (0.01%).

Question 54

[1032176] Which of the following statements is/are true with regard to an equity swap?
I
The payer receives a floating interest payment
II
The receiver pays for losses on the equity index
III
The receiver makes a floating interest rate payment
IV
The payer pays any losses on the equity index
A
III only
B
I and IV
C
I, II and III
D
All of the above
The correct answer is: C - I, II and III

Explanation

The payer in a swap pays away dividends and gains on the index to the receiver who in turn pays a floating interest rate.

Question 55

[1013411] I buy five FTSE 100 futures contracts at 6,000 and sell at 5,800. What is the profit/loss?
A
£10,000 profit
B
£10,000 loss
C
£2,000 profit
D
£2,000 loss
The correct answer is: B - £10,000 loss

Explanation

The total loss is 200 index points per contract x £10 per index point x 5 contracts = £10,000.

Question 56

[1066871] Match the following liability-driven investment strategies with either interest rate swaps or bespoke swaps.
I
Regular exchange of collateral
II
No direct collateral risk
III
Better approximation of required income
IV
Due diligence on counterparties
A
I, II Interest rate and inflation swaps, III, IV bespoke swaps
B
II, III Interest rate and inflation swaps, I, IV bespoke swaps
C
I, IV Interest rate and inflation swaps, II, III bespoke swaps
D
I, II, IV Interest rate and inflation swaps, III bespoke swaps
The correct answer is: C - I, IV Interest rate and inflation swaps, II, III bespoke swaps

Explanation

The use of interest rate and inflation swaps typically requires the regular exchange of collateral, and the investor has to manage due diligence on its counterparties. This can be a time consuming and costly process.

Question 57

[1066872] The use of interest rate and inflation swaps typically requires the regular exchange of collateral, and the investor has to manage due diligence on its counterparties. This can be a time consuming and costly process due to:
A
Plan surplus
B
Volatility of surplus
C
Surplus requirements
D
Surplus tracking error
The correct answer is: C - Surplus requirements

Explanation

LDIs focus on the plan surplus (assets minus liabilities) and the volatility of this surplus. Duration risk can be defined as surplus tracking error (i.e. the shortfall between actual and target surplus). A more sophisticated approach is to consider the volatility of this surplus and use it to assess the likelihood (or probability) of the surplus being a negative number at some time in the future.

Question 58

[1013409] What is the tick size of the FTSE 100 future?
A
One point
B
Half point
C
Two points
D
Quarter point
The correct answer is: B - Half point

Explanation

The minimum price movement (or tick) is half an index point. At £10 per index point, the tick value is £5.

Question 59

[1013432] If a call option with an exercise price of £4.00 is purchased for £1.50, what is the maximum loss? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in pounds sterling in the following format without symbols: 0.00
The correct answer is: 1.50 - 1.50

Explanation

If the option is out-the-money at expiry, the option will be abandoned and the premium will be lost.

Question 60

[1013437] Which of the following indices forms the basis of the NYSE Liffe UK stock index future?
A
FTSE All-share
B
FTSE 350
C
FTSE Small Cap
D
FTSE 100
The correct answer is: D - FTSE 100

Explanation

FTSE 100 index future and options are available on NYSE Liffe.

Question 1

[1017604] Real estate investment trusts (REITs) can be held in which of the following tax wrappers?
I
Individual saving account
II
Self-invested personal pension
III
Child trust funds
A
I and II
B
II and III
C
I, II, and III
D
I only
The correct answer is: C - I, II, and III

Explanation

Investors in REITs buy shares, and these typically trade on a regulated market such as the London Stock Exchange's official list. This qualifies them for inclusion in these tax efficient wrappers.

Question 2

[1066974] Which of the following statements about 'alternative investments' is FALSE?
A
No available benchmarks
B
Liquidity is often poor
C
Less regulation and therefore lower protection
D
Less efficient pricing
The correct answer is: A - No available benchmarks

Explanation

Benchmarks are available. For example in the property market, there are indices such as FTSE Commercial Property Index and FTSE All Property Index while Nationwide and Halifax building societies each produce an index for residential property.

Question 3

[1024383] If a REIT is to be exempt from paying corporation tax, how much of its income must it pass through to shareholders?
A
20%
B
50%
C
85%
D
90%
The correct answer is: D - 90%

Explanation

For a REIT to be exempt from paying corporation tax, it must pass through 90% of income to shareholders? Feedback from recent exams suggest there is a question on REITs.

Question 4

[1066971] Which of the following sectors is the largest investor in UK commercial property?
A
Pension funds
B
Unit trusts
C
Limited partnerships
D
Investment trust companies
The correct answer is: A - Pension funds

Explanation

Pension funds and insurance companies are the largest investors in commercial property.

Question 5

[1013461] Which of the following are characteristics of the property market?
I
Loose government regulation
II
Decentralised market
III
Management costs are an important consideration
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - II and III

Explanation

The property market is tightly controlled by the government (e.g. stamp duty/tax regimes etc). It is a decentralised market: i.e. property is not all traded in one place and subject to one set of supply and demand forces. Lastly, when buying a property to rent out, the return is going to be severely restricted by management costs.

Question 6

[1013457] An investor buys a property for rental purposes and pays £100,000 for it. A year later, the property is sold for £110,000, having received rental income of £6,000 (received at the year end). If the investor paid £600 in taxes and £2,000 in commissions, what annual rate of return has the investor received? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in percent in the following format without symbols: 00.00
The correct answer is: 13.40 - 13.40

Explanation

The investor's return is the capital gain plus income (£10,000 + £6,000 = £16,000) less tax and commissions (£600 + £2,000 = £2,600): £16,000 - £2,600 = £13,400 giving a return on the initial investment of £13,400/£100,000 = 13.4%.

Question 7

[1017599] Capital Property plc purchased No. 1 Park Lane for £2m, and incurred buying costs of £50,000. Assuming they let out the property at £300,000 per year and have expenses of £60,000, what is the rental yield? You should answer this question by typing the correct numbers in the following format without any symbols: 00.0
The correct answer is: 11.7 - 11.7

Explanation

Rental yield = gross rent - expenses / property cost + buying costs. Rental yield = £300k - £60k / £2m + £50k. Rental yield = £240k / £2,050,000 = 11.7%.

Question 8

[1017591] Venture capital trusts (VCT) are most similar in structure to which other collective investment vehicle?
A
OEIC
B
Investment trust
C
Unit trust
D
REIT
The correct answer is: B - Investment trust

Explanation

Venture capital trusts are constituted very much like an investment trust. However, their investment focus is specifically on smaller, higher-risk companies.

Question 9

[1013462] Which of the following contribute, to the inelasticity of supply in the property market?
I
Supply is easily increased
II
Planning controls
III
Geographic immobility
A
I and II
B
I and III
C
II and III
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: C - II and III

Explanation

Planning controls limit the supply of land available for development. Geographic immobility means that houses in one part of the country where there is a surplus cannot be moved to another part where there is a shortage.

Question 10

[1017609] Commercial property returns are typically measured in what way?
A
Rental yields
B
Net profits
C
Gross profits
D
Return on equity
The correct answer is: A - Rental yields

Explanation

Commercial property valuations are generally based on the net present value of rental yields.

Question 11

[1017607] What is the most accurate description of a venture capital trust (VCT)?
A
It is an investment trust that invests in other investment trusts
B
It is a quoted company on the London Stock Exchange that invests in other quoted companies
C
It is an investment trust that invests in unit trusts and OEICs
D
It is a quoted company on the London Stock Exchange that invests in unquoted companies
The correct answer is: D - It is a quoted company on the London Stock Exchange that invests in unquoted companies

Explanation

A VCT is a quoted company and is constituted in a very similar way to an investment trust company. The key difference is that its investment focus is on very small, riskier companies.

Question 12

[1066972] An investor looking to invest in the UK property market can do so using:
I
UCITs unit trusts
II
Unauthorised unit trusts
III
UK life bonds
IV
Investment trusts
A
I and IV
B
I, II and IV
C
I, III and IV
D
II, III and IV
The correct answer is: D - II, III and IV

Explanation

UCITs funds cannot invest in the property market.

Question 13

[1013466] Indirect property investment might involve which of the following:
I
Property bonds
II
Freehold or leasehold property
III
Shares in property companies
A
None of the above
B
I and III only
C
I and II only
D
II and III only
The correct answer is: B - I and III only

Explanation

Owning a freehold or a transferable lease on a property is direct investment.

Question 14

[1013459] Which of the following is/are TRUE of property bonds?
I
Represent shares in a property company
II
A form of indirect property investment
III
Coupons linked to rental income of property
A
I and II
B
II only
C
III only
D
II and III
The correct answer is: D - II and III

Explanation

Property bonds are bonds (not shares) issued by insurance companies. The funds raised are invested in real estate.

Question 15

[1017603] No single shareholder may hold more than what percentage of REIT capital?
A
5%
B
10%
C
15%
D
20%
The correct answer is: B - 10%

Explanation

The 10% maximum stake in a REIT is intended to prevent tax avoidance, primarily by property management companies who were given the opportunity to convert into REITs.

Question 16

[1013455] Which of the following is/are true of the property market?
I
It is heterogeneous
II
Property investments are generally indivisible
III
Returns include rental income
IV
Leasehold property returns may include ground rent
A
I, II, III and IV
B
I, II and IV
C
III only
D
I and II
The correct answer is: A - I, II, III and IV

Explanation

Heterogeneous means that no two pieces of property are exactly alike. Ground rent is rent paid by the leaseholder to the owner of the property every year. It is normally fixed, and if it rises with the value of the property each year it's known as 'rack rent'.

Question 17

[1017655] Which of the following is a chattel?
A
A second property
B
Reputation
C
A painting
D
Land
The correct answer is: C - A painting

Explanation

Chattels are tangible, moveable things. When used for investment purposes, they are sometimes also referred to as 'collectables'.

Question 18

[1024382] Which of the following statements is FALSE of holding a REIT?
A
The shares are liquid
B
Basic rate taxpayers pay tax at 10% on dividends received
C
They may be held inside an ISA
D
The REIT is exempt from corporation tax under certain circumstances
The correct answer is: B - Basic rate taxpayers pay tax at 10% on dividends received

Explanation

Basic rate tax payers pay tax at 20% on dividends received from a REIT. On all other dividends basic rate tax payers pay 10% not 20%. The shares are liquid, unlike directly holding the actual property, which is illiquid by comparison. REITs are ISA compliant, which means any dividends or capital gains are tax-free when held within an ISA. The REIT is exempt from corporation tax if it distributes 90% of its income to shareholders (they are often referred to as 'pass through' companies in this regard). Feedback from recent exams suggest that a question has appeared on REITs.

Question 1

[1024383] If a REIT is to be exempt from paying corporation tax, how much of its income must it pass through to shareholders?
A
20%
B
50%
C
85%
D
90%
The correct answer is: D - 90%

Explanation

For a REIT to be exempt from paying corporation tax, it must pass through 90% of income to shareholders? Feedback from recent exams suggest there is a question on REITs.

Question 2

[1012608] Which of the following are TRUE of investment trusts?
I
Closed-ended
II
Can borrow for gearing purposes
III
A sale of units reduces the size of the trust
A
I, II, III
B
I and II
C
I and III
D
II and III
The correct answer is: B - I and II

Explanation

Investment trusts are closed-ended - this means that they do NOT expand or contract in size when investments are bought and sold.

Question 3

[1013016] Which of the following does NOT apply to UK investment trusts and UK unit trusts?
A
They have similar asset composition
B
They are both limited to what they may invest in one company
C
They are both controlled by a board of trustees
D
They are both often named after their particular sector
The correct answer is: C - They are both controlled by a board of trustees

Explanation

Even though investment trusts have the word 'trust' in their name they are legally companies.

Question 4

[1012610] Which of the following types of pensions best describes a situation where an agreed level of contributions are paid by an individual and are invested over time to give a return?
A
Defined benefit
B
Defined contribution
C
SERPS
D
Occupational pension scheme
The correct answer is: B - Defined contribution

Explanation

A defined benefit scheme is one where the RETURN is guaranteed. A defined contribution scheme (or 'money purchase' scheme) best suits the description in the question.

Question 5

[1012609] Which of the following statements are true of qualifying life policies and personal pension plans?
I
Life policy premiums are paid net, but proceeds are received gross
II
Life policy premiums are paid gross, but proceeds are received net
III
Personal pension plans contributions are paid gross, but proceeds are received net
IV
Personal pension plans contributions are paid net, but proceeds are received gross
A
I and III
B
I and IV
C
II and III
D
II and IV
The correct answer is: A - I and III

Explanation

Tax relief is obtained at the time of investment for PPPs. Tax relief is received on life policies only on their maturity.

Question 6

[1066825] Hedge funds usually charge a:
A
Management fee of 5% and a performance fee of 25%
B
Flat fee irrespective of performance
C
Flat fee only if the fund has improved on its previous performance
D
Fixed fee of 1-2% and a management fee of 20-25%
The correct answer is: D - Fixed fee of 1-2% and a management fee of 20-25%

Explanation

The IMC uses the term 'fixed fee' to cover the cost independent of performance and management fee to cover the performance dependent cost.

Question 7

[1012598] Which of the following is/are true of unit trusts?
I
They are closed-ended in structure
II
They can borrow money for gearing purposes
III
A sale of units by the investor reduces the size of the trust
A
I, II, and III
B
II and III
C
III only
D
I and II
The correct answer is: C - III only

Explanation

Unit trusts are open-ended and are not allowed to borrow for gearing purposes.

Question 8

[1025264] Which of the following best describes an investment trust company?
A
It is a unitised collective investment scheme
B
It is a listed company that buys shares in other companies
C
It is a tax shelter for certain types of investment
D
It is an open-ended investment vehicle
The correct answer is: B - It is a listed company that buys shares in other companies

Explanation

Investment trusts are listed, exchange-tradable companies.

Question 9

[1012619] Long-term insurance is mainly concerned with which of the following products?
A
Life assurance
B
Permanent health insurance
C
Pensions
D
Property and pecuniary
The correct answer is: A - Life assurance

Explanation

Long-term business is primarily life business.

Question 10

[1012594] Which of the following is/are associated with investment trusts?
I
Closed-ended
II
May borrow money for gearing purposes
III
If an investor sells a share, the net asset value of the portfolio of the fund is affected
IV
They are approved by the FCA
A
I only
B
II only
C
I and II
D
I, II, III and IV
The correct answer is: C - I and II

Explanation

Shares in an investment trust are sold in the secondary market - as such the net asset value of the fund will NOT be affected.

Question 11

[1012658] Which of the following are classifications of hedge fund?
I
Event driven
II
Market neutral
III
Long/short funds
IV
Tactical trading
A
I, II, and III
B
I, II, III, and IV
C
III only
D
I, II, and IV
The correct answer is: B - I, II, III, and IV

Explanation

All of these represent general investment objectives of hedge funds.

Question 12

[1012617] Which of these statements about the manager and trustee of an authorised unit trust is FALSE?
A
They must be independent of each other
B
They must both be incorporated in the UK or another EU member state
C
They must both have a place of business in the UK or another EU member state
D
They must both be an authorised person
The correct answer is: C - They must both have a place of business in the UK or another EU member state

Explanation

They must both have a 'place of business' in the UK. They can both be incorporated in either the UK or another EEA state.

Question 13

[1012621] In what type of pension fund does the sponsoring company agree to pay members of the scheme a pre-determined percentage of salary, subject to the contributor's years of service?
A
Defined benefit
B
Defined contribution
C
Personal pension
D
Stakeholder pension
The correct answer is: A - Defined benefit

Explanation

Company pension schemes tend to be defined benefit; although, these are becoming less popular.

Question 14

[1012639] Which of the following factors would be considered in establishing the required rate of return for a defined benefit fund?
I
Mortality rates
II
Job transfers
III
Inflation
A
I and II only
B
I and III only
C
II and III only
D
I, II, and III
The correct answer is: D - I, II, and III

Explanation

The required rate of return for an occupational pension, such as a defined benefit scheme, would be calculated by an actuary. The actuary would have to take into account the average death rate in order to establish how long, on average, the pension is to be drawn from the fund. It is also important that the fund's return is kept above the prevailing inflation level. Job transfers would also be relevant.

Question 15

[1012758] With what would a UK pension fund manager managing a new portfolio be least concerned?
A
Future liabilities
B
Risk
C
Stock selection
D
Taxation
The correct answer is: D - Taxation

Explanation

Pension funds do not pay tax.

Question 16

[1012591] Which of the following are characteristics of companies offering life assurance rather than general insurance?
I
Short-term assets
II
High equity holding
III
Highly liquid assets
A
II and III
B
II only
C
I and III
D
I and II
The correct answer is: B - II only

Explanation

Life assurance funds cater for long-term liabilities - a higher proportion of equities are, therefore, more suitable.

Question 17

[1012635] Which of the following is/are true?
I
The proceeds of all life assurance policies are taxable
II
Income from pension funds is taxable
III
Contributions to pension funds are taxable
A
I only
B
II only
C
III only
D
I, II and III
The correct answer is: B - II only

Explanation

Proceeds from qualifying life assurance policies are tax-free (such as endowments), whilst proceeds from pensions are taxable. Contributions to pension funds are usually made from net earnings, but as tax relief is given on them it is fair to say that option III is false.

Question 18

[1012601] The manager of a pension fund, in considering possible investments in the UK equity sector, will need to be most concerned about:
A
Capital gains tax
B
Income tax
C
The transaction costs of buying and selling shares
D
Corporation tax
The correct answer is: C - The transaction costs of buying and selling shares

Explanation

Pension funds do not pay income, capital gains or corporation tax.

Question 19

[1012628] Which of the following is TRUE of unit trusts and investment trusts?
A
Both are open-ended
B
Both are closed-ended
C
Only unit trusts are trusts in the legal sense
D
Both are trusts in the legal sense
The correct answer is: C - Only unit trusts are trusts in the legal sense

Explanation

Unit trusts - open-ended trusts. Investment trusts - closed-ended companies.

Question 20

[1012618] Approved investment trusts:
I
Are open-ended
II
May make a rights issue
III
May borrow
A
I only
B
I and II only
C
I and III only
D
II and III only
The correct answer is: D - II and III only

Explanation

Investment trusts are closed-ended funds. They may borrow ('gear up').

Question 21

[1066822] Which of the following is not true of EIS investments?
A
It is a tax efficient scheme
B
Investments are made in small unquoted companies
C
The pooling of funds enables lower costs compared to a direct investment
D
Companies must have gross assets of less than £15m before (and no more than £16m after) the investment.
The correct answer is: C - The pooling of funds enables lower costs compared to a direct investment

Explanation

The enterprise investment scheme is a classification of small young company; it is not a type of collective investment scheme.

Question 22

[1031365] Which of the following are true of REITs?
I
90% of assets must be invested in real estate related activities to avoid taxation
II
75% of the assets must be invested in real estate related activities to avoid taxation
III
90% of income must be distributed to shareholders to avoid taxation
IV
75% of income must be distributed to shareholders to avoid taxation
A
I and IV
B
II and III
C
II and IV
D
I and III
The correct answer is: B - II and III

Explanation

For REITs to avoid taxation under subchapter M, 75% of the assets must be invested in real estate related activities, and 90% of income must be distributed to shareholders.

Question 23

[1012616] A unit trust is which of the following?
A
An open-ended company
B
A closed-ended company
C
An open-ended trust
D
A closed-ended trust
The correct answer is: C - An open-ended trust

Explanation

The number of units depends on demand: i.e. open-ended.

Question 24

[1012632] Which one of the following statements is correct in relation to unit trusts and investment trusts?
A
Only unit trusts are trusts in the legal sense
B
Only investment trusts are trusts in the legal sense
C
Both unit trusts and investment trusts are trusts in the legal sense
D
Neither unit trusts nor investment trust are trusts in the legal sense
The correct answer is: A - Only unit trusts are trusts in the legal sense

Explanation

Investment trusts are companies at law, whilst unit trusts are trusts.

Question 25

[1012638] Compared with life assurance funds, general insurance funds normally:
A
Hold shorter term assets
B
Hold more equities as a proportion of total assets
C
Have much longer liabilities
D
Hold less liquid assets
The correct answer is: A - Hold shorter term assets

Explanation

General insurance companies' liabilities are short-term, as the policies are for a maximum of a year, and any claims are submitted immediately. As a consequence, general insurance companies keep their funds in short-term assets.

Question 26

[1012605] Which of the following is NOT a collective investment scheme?
A
A regulated unit trust
B
An unauthorised unit trust
C
A self-select ISA
D
